TITLE.P: Scottish 4G Infill Programme: Capital Funded Mast Deployment Project

SHORT_DESCR.P: The Capital Funded Mast Deployment Project (the Project) is a capital grant funded intervention to deliver publicly available commercial 4G-LTE coverage from a fibre to the mast approach and provide next generation digital communications across some of the more remote and rural areas of Scotland. The Project allows for funding to be utilised to build masts up to a total value of 25m GBP. The Project is the first of a number of interventions which are to be advanced under the programme, with details of other interventions to be developed in due course.

Additional information about requirements can be found at https://www.publictendersscotland.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk and search for the following ITT: Scottish 4G Infill Programme: Capital Funded Mast Deployment Project.

The project meets the provisions of the Article 52 of General Block Exemption Regulations for State Aid funding and is exempt from the Public Sector Contract (Scotland) Regulations 2015 under Regulation 9.
The Project follows a single stage process similar to the open procedure provided for in the 2015 Regulations.
The Scottish Ministers are seeking to award the grant to a single Infrastructure Provider.

The Project allows for grant funding to be utilised to build masts up to a total value of 25 000 000 GPB to deliver next generation digital communications across some of the remote and rural areas of Scotland. This includes funding of up to 10 000 000 GBP from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to be used in the Highlands and Islands region of Scotland and up to 15 million GBP from Scottish Government to match fund the ERDF funding and wider development across Scotland. Scottish Government anticipates that approximately 60-70 masts can be delivered utilising the funds available for this Project.

The "Sustainable Procurement Duty", section 9 of Procurement Reform (Scotland) Act 2014, exemplifies the Scottish Model of Procurement, and places sustainable and socially responsible purchasing at the heart of the process. As such, Scottish Government are committed to pursuing through this procurement:
— The targeted recruitment and training of the long-term unemployed and those further from the job market (by way of apprenticeships, work placements etc.),

— Educational benefits to communities, including working closely with educational establishments and community groups to maximise educational opportunities that arise through performance of the agreement, increasing awareness, skills and digital accessibility,
— Awareness of opportunities, either in a prime or subcontracting role, for Small to Medium Sized businesses (SME) and social enterprises.

To facilitate progress in sustainable procurement, the National Performance Framework is the single framework to which all public services in Scotland are aligned. Supporting the National Performance Framework, the National Outcomes seek to reduce the local and global environmental impact of our consumption and production; to value and enjoy our built and natural environment and protect it and enhance it for future generations; to have strong, resilient and supportive communities where people take responsibility for their own actions and how they affect others. The tools created to support the Sustainable Procurement Duty, are directly linked to the National Outcomes. Accordingly, the contracts will include obligations in relation to social, economic and environmental considerations and other community benefits.
